explanation:
Explain why each symbol is needed for MISRA C string-bounds analysis:

- OS_task_prop_t
  Required to know the layout and sizes of the destination object (particularly the size of task_prop->name) used in memset and strncpy. The correctness of sizeof(OS_task_prop_t) and sizeof(task_prop->name) is central to determining if the string operations can overrun the destination.

- OS_common_record_t
  Defines the record structure returned from OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Needed to understand the type and properties of the source data (including name_entry) used by strncpy and to check any guarantees about its storage.

- OS_task_internal_record_t
  Included because the function reads task->stack_size and task->priority from it; while not directly string-related, its definition is needed to confirm that OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET returns valid pointers and to rule out any aliasing/overlap issues that could affect memory safety analyses.

- OS_common_record_t.name_entry
  The actual source passed to strncpy. You must know whether this member is a pointer or an embedded array, and if it is an array, its size — otherwise you cannot determine whether reading up to sizeof(task_prop->name)-1 bytes from it might read beyond its bounds.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro)
  Required to see how record and task pointers are derived from the token/array index (i.e., whether they point into fixed-size tables, name pools, or other storage that implies size guarantees for name_entry). This affects assumptions about source buffer sizes and lifetime.

- OS_global_task_table and OS_task_table
  Declarations/types for the tables accessed via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; necessary to determine where record->name_entry points (which table/region) and what guarantees exist about the size of name strings stored there.

- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro)
  The macro that checks task_prop; needed to verify whether it effectively guarantees task_prop != NULL (and how it reports failure). This influences whether subsequent use of task_prop is well-defined.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById (prototype and return semantics)
  Needed to understand success/failure conditions and whether, on success, the token/record pointers returned are guaranteed valid. Also to confirm when the strncpy and memset are executed (only on OS_SUCCESS).

- OS_object_token_t
  The token type used to index into object tables; understanding this type may be necessary to trace how OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET computes addresses and hence the provenance/size guarantees of name_entry.

- OS_SUCCESS
  The constant checked to determine whether the function proceeds to access record and task; required to reason about control flow and when string functions are invoked.

- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE and OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL
  These parameters to OS_ObjectIdGetById can affect which table/namespace is queried and therefore what kind of record/name storage is returned. They are needed to resolve which object table and name storage layout apply.

- strncpy (from <string.h>)
  The string-copy function used. Its exact semantics (number of bytes read from the source when no NUL is present, no automatic trailing NUL if source length >= n, etc.) must be considered to determine whether the call can read beyond the source bounds or otherwise violate the MISRA rule.

- memset (from <string.h>)
  Used to clear task_prop; included so the analyzer can verify the size argument and that the destination pointer is valid for the requested size.

- OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl (prototype and behavior)
  Called after the structure fields are copied/initialized. It receives task_prop and may modify it (including its name buffer). To fully assess whether the target function (as a whole) results in any out-of-bounds string access, the implementation or contract of OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl must be known (does it write into task_prop->name, and with what bounds?).

Note: The above symbols are the minimum needed to determine whether the strncpy/memset usages can legally access only the intended object bounds. In particular, you must be able to determine the size and storage characteristics of the source (name_entry) and destination (task_prop->name) buffers and the guarantees provided by the object-table access macros.
